last_post.content: Finally read this piece: “‘There’s a narcissism that reemerges in the AI dream that we are going to prove that everything we thought was distinctively human can actually be accomplished by machines + accomplished better,” Judith Butler [told me]. ‘Or that human potential — that’s the fascist idea — human potential is more fully actualized with AI than without it.’ The AI dream is ‘governed by the perfectibility thesis, + that’s where we see a fascist form of the human.’” https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/ai-artificial-intelligence-chatbots-emily-m-bender.html

title: Samsung "space zoom" moon shots are fake, and here is the proof

last_post.content:
Samsung is replacing actual pictures you take of the moon with a fake AI version that is crystal clear.

This is pretty terrifying. The phone software can identify objects in pictures and replace them.

How long until they're replacing the content of billboards in the backgrounds of your pictures with whoever pays for it? What if they decide you can't record encounters with the police, and it automatically blurs the face of the police?

title: The Incredible Tantrum Venture Capitalists Threw Over Silicon Valley Bank

last_post.content:
The risk introduced to SVB by overreliance on low interest rates in both its depositor base and portfolio investments is the same risk embedded in the core of the venture capital model. Profligate fundraising and investment have operated on the assumption that money would be cheap, allowing it to make increasingly exotic bets. Venture capitalists have had a decade of negative to zero real interest rates to build the future through their intrepid noses for value, so what did they give us? We got benefits largely limited to the realm of consumer goods and services, like cheap on-demand delivery and ride-hail (so long as you ignored the exploitation that powered them) and cheap streaming services (until they began hiking prices), namely. But what were the costs? Startups that revolutionized the militarization of our border and our migrant deportation operations, helped weaponize robots, offered A.I. services that exploit invisible underpaid workers in the Global South, and roiled urban transit, rental, and restaurant markets. These projects and others generated billions for investors who got in on an early fundraising round, but they also degraded the quality of life for people across the world.

https://slate.com/technology/2023/03/silicon-valley-bank-rescue-venture-capital-calacanis-sacks-ackman-tantrum.html

title: Microsoft was already using OpenAI’s GPT-4 model for the Bing AI chatbot

last_post.content:
Bing has been using GPT-4. I guess Microsoft was calling the model Prometheus to avoid admitting it was GPT-4.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/3/14/23639928/microsoft-bing-chatbot-ai-gpt-4-llm

This explains some of Bing's erratic behavior. GPT-4 would have completed training well before ChatGPT was put together, and thus would not have had all the RLHF advances. Microsoft must have also done some of it's own fine-tuning to teach it to respond to Sydney.

title: Bird Deaths Down 70 Percent After Painting Wind Turbine Blades - The Study Ran For Nine Years At Norway's Smøla Wind Farm - GadgeteerZA

last_post.content:
Bird deaths down 70 percent after painting wind turbine blades – The study ran for nine years at Norway’s Smøla wind farm

Something as simple as black paint could be the key to reducing the number of birds that are killed each year by wind turbines. According to a study conducted at a wind farm on the Norwegian archipelago of Smøla, changing the color of a single blade on a turb ...continues

See https://gadgeteer.co.za/bird-deaths-down-70-percent-after-painting-wind-turbine-blades-the-study-ran-for-nine-years-at-norways-smola-wind-farm/

title: GitHub - MiMoText/roman18: Collection de romans français du dix-huitième siècle (1751-1800) / Collection of Eighteenth-Century French Novels (1751-1800)

last_post.content: Heute läuft der Datathon des Workshops zu #Datendokumentation. Mit dabei ist die Romansammlung „roman18“ (https://github.com/MiMoText/roman18), 205 frz. Romane (1750-1800) aus dem Projekt „Mining and Modeling Text“ (#MiMoText, @CDHTrier), hrsg. von meiner Kollegin Julia Röttgermann. #DHd2023 😀

Ein Tag, an dem man gerne viele wäre und sich aufteilen möchte: so viele super Workshops heute bei der #DHd2023!! Ich bin bei der #Datendokumentation, denn da gibt es am Nachmittag einen Datathon, bei dem ich die Daten aus dem Adressbuch der Deutschen in Paris von 1854 vorstelle =>https://adressbuch1854.dhi-paris.fr/

I’m almost-speechless Microsoft chose this moment to confirm the views of the harshest sceptics of #AIethics (like me), just as it goes all-out on #OpenAI https://open.substack.com/pub/platformer/p/microsoft-just-laid-off-one-of-its?r=4ba8u&utm_medium=ios&utm_campaign=post

One of the key lessons of American civic life is that there doesn't have to be a good guy in the story.

title: President, law school dean apologize to Judge Kyle Duncan for ‘disruption’ to his speech

last_post.content:
Stanford was right to apologize. This is an embarrassment to the institution. Denounce the speaker online or shun the Federalists who invited the speaker or protest outside the venue. But preventing the speaker from speaking and the attendees from listening? That's totalitarian shitbirdery and ought to make law students unemployable.

https://stanforddaily.com/2023/03/12/president-law-school-dean-apologize-to-judge-kyle-duncan-for-disruption-to-his-speech/

title: Docker is sunsetting Free Team organizations | Hacker News

last_post.content:
Say what you will about Heroku unceremoniously getting rid of their free tiers and screwing over significant parts of the open source ecosystem, at least they gave more warning than DockerHub.

If you're on the free tier at DockerHub, you have 30 days before services get shut off and 60 days before all your data is deleted:

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35153949

title: How AI Could Write Our Laws - Schneier on Security

last_post.content: As if it wasn't terrifying enough: https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2023/03/how-ai-could-write-our-laws.html

The Atlassian Acceptable Use Policy https://www.atlassian.com/legal/acceptable-use-policy still says they won't allow "Disparaging Atlassian or our partners, vendors, or affiliates". Not limited to "on our Services" -- so, at all, anywhere!

I believe I first noticed this when @robla pointed it out like 10 years ago. Still there, still raises an eyebrow.

title: The Infinite Catalog of Crushed Dreams

last_post.content: When I released *The Infinite Catalog of Crushed Dreams* some people asked what AI model I used and what data it was trained on. Haha. The model I used was MFE-48. My Fucking Experiences. And its training data was Heartache, Pain, and Woe, with a temperature of .666666666666… https://fugitivetexts.net/pandemicdreams/

It was an easy prediction to make, given #OpenAI 's track record for sure. Still, I could wish that it wasn't so thoroughly validated.

They are willfully ignoring the most basic risk mitigation strategies, all while proclaiming themselves to be working towards the benefit of humanity.

https://sigmoid.social/@Riedl/110023271456110373

On this day of the many language models, consider reading some thoughtful takes on generated text and writing:

Language models can only write poetry
by Allison Parrish @aparrish
https://posts.decontextualize.com/language-models-poetry/

When machines change art
by Aaron Hertzmann
https://aaronhertzmann.com/2022/12/17/when-tech-changes-art.html

On artificial and post-artificial texts
by Hannes Bajohr @hannesbajohr
https://hannesbajohr.de/en/2023/03/11/on-artificial-and-post-artificial-texts/

The flood of ChatGPT crap about to clog up publishing
by Lincoln Michel
https://countercraft.substack.com/p/the-flood-of-chatgpt-crap-about-to?utm_source=substack

title: Using the NASA Openscapes Framework to enable open science

last_post.content:
RT National Snow and Ice Data Center:

As @NASA
moves their data over to the Earthdata Cloud, they are leaning on @openscapes
. Openscapes developed a scalable leadership training & community-building framework to support NASA DAAC researchers in migrating workflows to the cloud. Learn more: https://nsidc.org/news-analyses/news-stories/using-nasa-openscapes-framework-enable-open-science
